jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5366: ARROW-6520: [Python] More consistent handling of specified schema when creating Table table arrays schema
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5366#discussion_r323803652
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/array.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -225,7 +225,7 @@ def asarray(values, type=None):
     -------
     arr : Array
     """
-    if isinstance(values, Array):
+    if isinstance(values, (Array, ChunkedArray)):
         if type is not None and not values.type.equals(type):
             values = values.cast(type)
 
 Review comment:
   So we have a `asarray` function that will cast an Array to the appropriate type if needed. I added support for ChunkedArray as well, as that makes it easier to handle both Array and ChunkedArray in other places. 
   Are we OK with that? (it's a bit inconsistent with the name of the function)
   
   (if so, still need to update the docstring)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5366: ARROW-6520: [Python] More consistent handling of specified schema when creating Table table arrays schema
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5366#discussion_r323806540
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -1525,7 +1522,7 @@ def record_batch(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
         return TypeError("Expected pandas DataFrame or python dictionary")
 
 
-def table(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
+def table(data, schema=None, names=None, metadata=None):
 
 Review comment:
   @wesm so I took the approach of switching the order. That is backwards compatible, and allows to raise a good error message if you are passing names for a wrong data type (and since `schema` is the only keyword valid for all three types, makes sense to put it first).
   
   But you did it originally this way to match the order of `from_arrays` ? 
   
   Happy to switch again, and pass `names` to `schema` of the underlying mehod when appropriate, potentially with a deprecation warning.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on pull request #5366: ARROW-6520: [Python] More consistent handling of specified schema when creating Table table arrays schema
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5366#discussion_r323890872
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -1525,7 +1522,7 @@ def record_batch(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
         return TypeError("Expected pandas DataFrame or python dictionary")
 
 
-def table(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
+def table(data, schema=None, names=None, metadata=None):
 
 Review comment:
   Yeah I wanted `pa.table(data, names)` to work. All things being equal that's still my preference. Do you see a downside to accepting either `names` or `schema` as the second positional argument? 
   
   ```
   pa.table(data, schema)
   ```
   
   vs
   
   ```
   pa.table(data, names)
   ```
   
   It doesn't leave a lot of ambiguity about the user's intent in this case
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5366: ARROW-6520: [Python] More consistent handling of specified schema when creating Table table arrays schema
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5366#discussion_r323940684
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -1525,7 +1522,7 @@ def record_batch(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
         return TypeError("Expected pandas DataFrame or python dictionary")
 
 
-def table(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
+def table(data, schema=None, names=None, metadata=None):
 
 Review comment:
   Not a specific downside, but more a general dislike of such "loose" APIs as those are an invitation for corner cases. 
   But I certainly see the usability upside as well for this case.
   
   For RecordBatch.from_arrays you deprecated passing schema as the first argument (https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/c3a68781204d36f568e3b1f15dc517a4c58650a4/python/pyarrow/table.pxi#L723-L729), you wouldn't do that here?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on pull request #5366: ARROW-6520: [Python] More consistent handling of specified schema when creating Table table arrays schema

 ##########

         return TypeError("Expected pandas DataFrame or python dictionary")
 
 
-def table(data, names=None, schema=None, metadata=None):
+def table(data, schema=None, names=None, metadata=None):
 
 Review comment:
   I'm not big on loose APIs either. I think it's OK in this case but we shouldn't get in the habit of trying to guess the user's intent in general. 
   
   Another option is to add a dummy `_1=` keyword argument for the positional argument case.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [Python] Segmentation fault on writing tables with fixed size binary fields
fields.environment: python(3.7.3), pyarrow(0.14.1), arrow-cpp(0.14.1), parquet-cpp(1.5.1), Arch Linux x86_64

comments.body: Seems like there's an unhandled case somewhere in the write path. This should work -- I added to 0.15.0. Are you able to take a look at the C++ code?

I can reproduce this on 0.14.1, but not any more on master. So it might already be fixed. 

Will do a PR with adding a test to see if it passes on CI as well.
Could not reproduce with latest master. I'll add a test case though.
[~jorisvandenbossche] Didn't see your comment, are you handling it?

So this is due to an invalid creation of the table in 0.14.1. With the table as created above:

{code}
 In [4]: table.column(0)                                                                                                                                                                                            
Out[4]: 
<Column name='col' type=FixedSizeBinaryType(fixed_size_binary[4])>
[
  [
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334,
    31323334
  ]
]

In [5]: table.column(0).type 
Out[5]: FixedSizeBinaryType(fixed_size_binary[4])

In [7]: table.column(0).data.chunk(0).type
Out[7]: DataType(binary)
{code}

So the Column (now gone) and ChunkedArray are of FixedSizeBinary type, but the actual Array that they are holding is variable binary type. This is probably related to the fixed issue where the passed schema was not properly used (there have been several PRs related to that I think, eg https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5189. We now also validate the created table in cython).
[~kszucs] yes, will add a test case for the table creation (not related to parquet)

So the reason it was passing on master, is because it was not actually testing it. The signature of {{pa.table}} changed, and now the first argument is names and not schema, and when passing a schema as such it was silently ignored. Will open a separate JIRA for this.

Then, when trying to do this properly, it now fails on master (which is better down creating an invalid array as before). It boils down to this:

{code}
In [31]: arr = pa.array([b"1234" for _ in range(10)])  

In [32]: pa.array(arr, type=pa.binary(4)) 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ArrowTypeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-32-4651f2f37039> in <module>
----> 1 pa.array(arr, type=pa.binary(4))

~/scipy/repos/arrow/python/pyarrow/array.pxi in pyarrow.lib.array()

~/scipy/repos/arrow/python/pyarrow/array.pxi in pyarrow.lib._sequence_to_array()

~/scipy/repos/arrow/python/pyarrow/error.pxi in pyarrow.lib.check_status()

ArrowTypeError: Expected a string or bytes object, got a 'pyarrow.lib.BinaryValue' object
{code}

So due to some changes (I think a bit buried in the Column removal PR: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4841), we started calling {{pa.array}} on the values in the dict, but, we do not yet accept actual pyarrow arrays in {{pa.array}} (see ARROW-5295). And apparently we did not yet have the case of a dict of arrow arrays + specifying a schema covered in our tests.
There's several layers of rottenness here. I'll work on a patch that addresses these rough edges

[~wesmckinn] ah, I started looking at it as well. Sorry should have noted here (only mentioned it on the standup). Now, I went away for dinner so didn't do anything worthy of actual code yet, but I was planning to:

- accept `pyarrow.Array` in `pyarrow.array` and if a `type` is specified try to `cast` it to that type (which will still mean that the example of the top post will now fail, as we don't have a cast from var binary to fixed size binary). This should then also fix `from_dict` using `pyarrow.array(.. type=type)` on all input.
- switch the order of the `names` and `schema` keywords of the `pyarrow.table` factory function to preserve backwards compatibility.
Yes, that was basically my thinking except to handle a Schema passed to {{names=}} as though it were passed as {{schema=}}
I haven't gotten to this yet, so if you have time tomorrow in Europe to take it on just let me know here
